ul.li: \(\mathrm{assume}\) assertion - something to be ensured by the user outside the program, generally reflects input specification (e.g. if algorithm requires a sorted array as a parameter, we can \(\mathrm{assume}\text{ }\mathrm{is\_sorted}(a)\))
\(\mathrm{@}\) assertion - something which should be implied by the algorithm, generally reflects output specification of a portion of the code and is to be verified (e.g. \(\mathrm{@} z \geq 0\))
A program execution is regular iff it satisfies all assume-assertions. (i.e. iff user supplied valid arguments)
A program is partially correct iff every regular program execution the first program line to a line with \(\mathrm{@}\)-assertion satisfies this \(\mathrm{@}\)-assertion
A program is totally correct iff it is partially correct and terminates

note.div: Static Single Assignment = formulation of the program such that all variables are immutable and mutability is expressed by creation of new variables (e.g. \(x = x - 2\) would be rewritten as \(x_2 \leftarrow x_1 - 2\))

For programs without control structures, verification condition is formula consisting of implication which has program statements in SSA on the left hand side, and an \(\mathrm{@}\)-assertion on the right hand side.
Example program with assertions and verification condition:
If-then-else control structures decided by \(P\) must be linearized into two basic paths where one assumes \(P\) and the other assumes \(\neg P\)

While-do control structures decided by \(P\) must be linearized into two basic paths, one entering or re-entering the loop (\(\mathrm{assume}\text{ } P\)) and the other leaving or jumping over the loop (\(\mathrm{assume}\text{ } \neg P\)).

Loop invariants are \(\mathrm{@}\)-assertions which mainly serve to prove that loops terminate.
A loop invariant is correct iff it holds for all executions (no assertion failure)
A loop invariant is inductive iff all verification conditions ending in this loop invariant are true
To prove that a loop terminates, we use loop variants. Generally this could be thought of as a values assigned to each loop, and which are ordered and bounded.
